· Target title: Put the target job title at the top of your resume
· Embolden metrics: 80% or more bullet points should include a metric in bold
· Customize the first bullet: Speak to a key requirement on the Job Description
· Branding: Use target company's brand color as your accent color

post_html:
🚀 QUICK RESUME TIP 🚀

Job hunting? Here’s a game-changer: Paste your resume into ChatGPT and ask for suggestions on making it ATS-friendly!

Here’s how to optimize your resume:

1️⃣ Keep It Simple: Avoid tables, text boxes, or graphics—ATS systems may misread them. Stick to clean, standard section headings like "Professional Experience," "Skills," and "Education."

2️⃣ Use Keywords: Add role-specific terms like “calendar management,” “travel coordination,” “process improvement,” or “C-suite support” for an Executive Assistant role.

3️⃣ Be Consistent: Use uniform formatting—bold headings, bullet points for achievements, and a clear, easy-to-read font.

4️⃣ Quantify Results: Add metrics or measurable achievements (e.g., “Cut vendor costs by 20% through renegotiations”).

A well-formatted resume is easier for ATS systems to process and catches the eye of human recruiters.

➕ Follow Vishal Ravi for daily insights on productivity and leadership.

hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#ATSFriendlyResume hashtag#ResumeWriting hashtag#JobHuntingTips hashtag#ProfessionalGrowth

post_html:
Your Resume is Your First Impression—Make It Count!



Did you know recruiters spend an average of 7 seconds scanning your resume?

That’s less time than it takes to check a text message!

In a job market overflowing with talent, your resume isn’t just a piece of paper—it’s your Personal brand, your story, and your ticket to a dream job.

Yet, so many job seekers miss the mark by:
❌ Overloading it with irrelevant information
❌ Using vague phrases like “team player” or “results-oriented”
❌ Ignoring the power of tailoring for every role.


So, how do you stand out? Here are 3 quick tips to make your resume shine:

1️⃣ Start with a punchy summary: Replace bland objectives with a dynamic summary that showcases your unique value.
2️⃣ Quantify your achievements: “Increased sales by 30%” > “Responsible for sales growth.” Numbers speak louder than words!
3️⃣ Optimize for ATS: Use keywords from the job description and keep the formatting simple. Fancy fonts won’t land you the job—clarity will.


𝗝𝗼𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝘆 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝗹𝘂𝘀𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗱𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗷𝗼𝗯.🚀

75% of resumes never reach a human—they’re rejected by ATS bots in seconds. 🤖

If your resume isn’t optimized, you’re missing out on 90% of opportunities before you even start.

A polished resume isn’t just a document—it’s your first impression, your pitch, and your ticket to interviews.

✅ 𝗙𝗶𝘅 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀 𝗡𝗢𝗪:
▪ 🚨 Outdated formats (ATS can’t read fancy designs)
▪ 🚨 Vague language (“Hard worker” ≠ “Increased sales by 40%”)

▪ 🚨 Missing keywords (Mirror the job description!)
▪ 🚨 Typos and errors (One typo = 50% fewer callbacks)

“The job market’s just tough” ❌ → Your resume’s the problem ✅

Revamp your resume with data-driven bullets, ATS-friendly layouts, and ruthless editing—watch interviews pour in.

post_html:
📝 2025 Resumes: Quality Over Quantity
When it comes to crafting your resume, remember: less is more—as long as it’s meaningful.
✅ Keep It Concise
Aim for no more than 5 bullet points per position. Focus on well-constructed statements that paint a complete picture of your accomplishments and daily responsibilities.

🎯 Highlight What Matters
Hiring managers would much rather see fewer, high-quality bullet points than a long list of generic tasks. It’s all about showcasing the value you brought to the role.

⏳ Tailor Older Roles
For positions further back in your career, scale down to just the most relevant details that align with your current career path or the role you’re applying for.

Remember, your resume isn’t about listing everything you’ve done—it’s about communicating your impact. ✨

hashtag#resumetips hashtag#jobsearch

post_html:
I often get referrals from colleagues in my network asking me to chat with someone who's going through a job transition. When I meet with them, I share this advice:

Get out of your own head. Whatever the reason for your transition, be confident in who you are. Don't start second-guessing yourself or the reasons for the change. Learn from the past when needed and move forward. Now is not the time for imposter syndrome.

Start by making a list of work that genuinely inspires you. About 70% of high-performing professionals find success by aligning their passion with their profession. What truly brings you joy at work?

Next, make a list of organizations you admire within the geography you want to work. Research these organizations looking for clues that relate to your list. This should include checking their websites, Glassdoor, and asking friends and colleagues. You may discover companies you didn't even know existed.

Start networking. The days of just applying for a job and hoping your resume gets picked are over. Begin by checking your admired organization's LinkedIn page for connections you know, or people who can introduce you to key contacts. Look at open roles that might interest you, but remember, new roles are created all the time when the right person shows up. Doing this can get your resume in front of the actual hiring manager.

Lastly, tell everyone you meet that you're looking for work – even your dog groomer might know of an awesome role through one of their customers (to be clear, you want input from the dog parents, not the dog 😊).

All this will transform your job search from transactional to transformational. Position yourself as a strategic solution, not just a candidate. Organizations invest in professionals who solve complex challenges.

Remember: Companies hire potential, not just past achievements. Highlight your unique value and show how your skills can drive organizational success.

🏅 What tips do you have that have worked for you in your search?


hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#CareerStrategy hashtag#NetworkingTips hashtag#Jobsearch

post_html:
The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.

NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.

START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.

INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.

FORCE YOUR INTERVIEWER TO TAKE A POSITION ON MARTIN LUTHER: Divinely inspired reformer, or blasphemous oaf? Both positions are respectable, but make them take a side, and more importantly, defend it.

END WITH A SONG: Most interviewers end interviews with "Do you have any more questions?" This is when you queue up some music and say, "Just one: do you enjoy Billy Joel's middle period?" That's when you can delight them with a rendition of "Uptown Girl" or "Allentown." Don't go for B-Sides like "Big Man on Mulberry Street" or "Running on Ice" you'll just be wasting everyone's time.

Hope this helps! Feel free to leave your favorite job-landing tip below!
post_text:
The secret to landing that dream job? It's so simple.

NEVER USE PDFs FOR YOUR RESUME. Too easy for your prospective hiring manager to open. Make them work for it. Use a weird format like .BMP or .Tiff. This provides an air of mystery to your resume. "What could this be? How the hell do I even open a TARGA file in 2025?" Hiring managers love puzzle solving, so give them something they can really sink their teeth into.

START INTERVIEWS BY REVEALING A TRAGIC FAMILY SECRET: You can make one up if you need to. "My grandpa could have stopped Ted Bundy, but didn't" is a good one. "Every one of my uncles is a horse thief" is more niche, but there's a timeless quality to it. My tip? Have fun with it.

INSIST ON BEING PAID IN RARE JEWELS: Inflation, shmilflation! Sure, it may take a few extra steps, but nothing spends better than a sack full of sapphires, emeralds, and diamonds. Slapping down a topaz at the local five and dime is a real flex.

post_html:
I reviewed 4,000+ resumes last year. Here’s an anonymized Software Engineer resume. Let's roast it together ➡️


It’s a good resume, but small changes can double their chances of landing interviews.

Recruiters spend 6 (!) seconds per resume, so the first impression matters.


Some of the most common mistakes and what to do instead:

OVERDESIGNING

❌ Using progress bars, decorative elements, overdesigning

✅ Keeping design as simple as possible


DESIGNING FOR READING, NOT SCANNING

❌ Long paragraphs, less bulleted lists

✅ Bulleted lists, using the bold or italic font to highlight some experiences


SHORT EXPERIENCE DESCRIPTIONS

❌ Focusing too much on education, certifications, etc.

✅ Experience description should take up to 70-80% of the resume


NO COMPANY DESCRIPTIONS

❌ Listing company names without context.

✅ Adding 1-sentence company/product descriptions.


RESPONSIBILITIES OVER ACHIEVEMENTS

❌ "Managed projects and oversaw deadlines."

✅ "Led 3+ cross-functional teams, delivering 7 projects on time with a 98% client satisfaction rate.”


IRRELEVANT INFO

❌ Adding technologies you are not using anymore.

✅ Adding information relevant to the role you’re applying for


Comment “template” - and I’ll send you this EDITABLE FIGMA TEMPLATE.


I'm Kris Holysheva 👋
Follow me for more hiring tips.

8 Insider Tips to Instantly Transform Your Resume!

As a resume builder, I've seen it all: from cluttered timelines to outdated formats. Here's what I've learned from reviewing over 1000 resumes...
✅Ditch the Objective Statement
✅Show Results, Not Tasks
✅Proofread Like Your Career Depends on It

The best ones grab attention in the first 5 seconds. If you want your resume to be one of those, here's my advice:
1️⃣Update Your Resume Monthly:
Trust me, it's easy to forget the things you've accomplished. I didn't believe it myself until I looked back at what I did 6 months ago. Keep track while it's fresh!
2️⃣Maintain a "Master Resume":
Think of it as a long-form version that captures all your achievements, projects and responsibilities.

Why?
►It saves you from scrambling when a job opportunity pops up.
►You can tailor it easily for specific roles without stretching the truth.

🗝️Pro Tip: Keeping this document up-to-date will make your job search smoother and more intentional.

Need a resume that gets results? Let me help you craft a winning one!🎯

post_html:
Want to stand out in today's job market? You absolutely need to try these TOTALLY not terrible tips.


Forget the usual advice.

People will try and tell you to tailor your resume for each job, build your network, optimize your LinkedIn profile....blah blah blah.

We all know that doesn't work.

If you REALLY want to grab a recruiter's attention, here's what DEFINTIELY works:

1. Make your resume as long as it needs to be!

Have 20 years of experience?

Document everything and make your resume 12 pages long!

Nothing says "Top candidate" like making recruiters work hard to find the important information.

Bonus points if you use size 8 font for your entire resume!

2. Apply to the same job 37 times!

They'll have to notice you eventually right?

Persistence? Yes.

Stalking? That's for you to decide.

3. Make sure your LinkedIn photo is a selfie from the club!

Employers LOVE a candidate who is the life of the party.

It's great for the culture!

4. Slide into a recruiter's DM's at 2AM and ask for an update on your application.

It's well-timed and will help you stand out because you have a better chance of being noticed as the only person to message them when they are trying to sleep!

I could offer more (great) job searching advice but I don't want to "spill all the tea" in one post.

Do you have any other "great" career advice tips that you would like to share?

Let me know in the comments!

Have a great Saturday everyone!

hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#careertips hashtag#humor hashtag#smile hashtag#jobseekers hashtag#standouttherightway

post_html:
A recent resume update led to significant changes in my job application results.

Initially, using an older layout, I faced multiple rejections and no callbacks. However, after revamping the layout, I secured two calls the day after applying and noticed increased recruiter interest on LinkedIn.

Here are my key tips for resume success:

🤖 **𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗼𝘁:** Structure your resume with key information at the top, especially technical skills relevant to the job. This increases the chances of passing through ATS systems effectively.

 💡 **𝗔𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀:** Tailor your resume to match the job requirements closely. Aim for a score of 90+ to enhance your chances.

 💯 **𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗳𝘆 𝗮𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗰𝘀:** Avoid fancy designs and formatting. Opt for a clean layout with hyphens instead of bullet points for better ATS compatibility.

Ensuring your resume aligns with the job description and is ATS-friendly can significantly boost your application success rate.

My approach, guided by ChatGPT as an ATS scorer, involved iterative edits to achieve scores between 80-85, refining further for each specific job until hitting a 90+ score.

Let's get some wins!

post_html:
5 easy tips to smarten up your resume:


1. Use a readable font and consistent formatting. Avoid random fonts and sizes, excessive styling and bulk paragraphs.

2. Make it concise. Your CV does not need to be longer than 2 pages.

3. Use a clear structure. Header with name, contact info, key achievements followed by role title (Include dates and country) and qualifications.

4. Proofread for spelling mistakes or sentence repetition.

5. Save your CV as a PDF with your name.

post_html:
The painful truth about ATS "hacks" that no one's talking about...

I see job seekers spending countless hours:
✔️ Cramming keywords
✔️ Using white text
✔️ Creating complex tables
✔️ Testing "perfect" formatting tricks

Here's the reality: Modern ATS systems are FAR more sophisticated than you think. Those outdated hacks from 2015? They might actually be hurting your chances.

Instead, focus on what truly matters:

Write for humans first, ATS second The hiring manager needs to WANT to read your resume. Clear, compelling achievements beat keyword stuffing every time.

Use clean, standard formatting Simple beats clever. Period. Your beautifully formatted resume means nothing if it's unreadable to human eyes.

Tailor with intention Don't just mirror job descriptions. Understand the role's core needs and demonstrate your relevant impact.

Remember: The goal isn't to "beat" the ATS. It's to reach the hiring manager's desk with a resume that makes them want to meet you.

Pro tip: Want to test your resume? Send it to yourself as a plain text file. If it's readable there, most ATS systems will handle it just fine.

Want to check your resume's ATS score? Drop "Score" in the comments - I'll carryout a free ATS scan on your resume and share the result with you.

Repost for someone who needs to hear this and follow Seun Ige for more of this

post_html:
I've seen tons of resumes. Here are some common pitfalls I've seen:

1️⃣ Overloading with Text: Keep it clean and concise. Highlight your top achievements instead of listing every responsibility individually.

2️⃣ Skipping Keywords: Tailor your resume to the job by using keywords from the posting. Yes, this is an extra step, but it's worth it.

3️⃣ Generic Summaries: Customize your summary to show how you bring unique value to the role that you're applying for.

4️⃣ Ignoring Metrics: Use numbers to show impact. For example: "Increased efficiency by 30%" is much stronger than "Improved processes."

5️⃣ Formats: Resumes should be sleek and ATS-friendly. Stick to a design that’s easy to read.

Follow, Connect or DM for more. 🚀

What are your biggest resume pet peeves? Drop them in the comments—I’d love to hear! 👇

hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#Interviewing

post_html:
Applying for a Job Without Researching the Company? 🚩
That’s like going on a blind date without knowing anything about the person! 😬
🔴 What Happens When You Don’t Research?
 ❌ You struggle to answer “Why do you want to work here?”
 ❌ You might not align with the company’s culture or values.
 ❌ You risk walking into a bad work environment.
 ❌ You miss the chance to tailor your resume & interview answers.
✅ What to Do Instead?
 🔍 Check the company’s website, mission, values, & recent news.
 💼 Explore their LinkedIn, Glassdoor, & employee reviews.
 📝 Understand their work culture & expectations.
 🎯 Tailor your resume & interview responses to show alignment.
📌 A little research goes a long way! It helps you stand out, feel confident, & land the right job. 🚀
Have you ever applied without researching? Share your experience! ⬇️

Even if recruiters spend 3 seconds reading it,
don't neglect it.

It's most likely the first point of contact.
Your first impression.
Don't make it the last one.

As design is primarily a visual discipline,
you focus most of your attention on the portfolio.
That makes sense, but if you neglect your resume,
your portfolio might never be seen.

Here's the list of things to consider when working on a resume.

• Ensure proper metadata in the PDF properties
• Use vector formats for any icons or graphics
• Keep the document resolution at 300 DPI
• Test the resume's readability in grayscale
• Don't use Figma for ATS-compatible resumes
• Check contrast ratios meet WCAG AA standards at minimum
↓ more of them in the attached doc.

✌️

P.S. What is your favorite tip for resumes?

📝 What Makes a Resume ATS-Friendly?
🔹 𝐂𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 – Stick to standard section titles like "Work Experience," "Education," and "Skills" to ensure the ATS can process it properly.

🔹 𝐒𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐅𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 – Avoid complex designs, tables, or graphics that might confuse the system.

🔹 𝐔𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐑𝐢𝐠𝐡𝐭 𝐊𝐞𝐲𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐝𝐬 – Including relevant terms from the job description helps match your resume to the role.

🔹 𝐑𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐅𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐬 – Stick to professional, easy-to-read fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri.

🔹 𝐓𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 – A resume customized for each job always performs better.

post_html:
Resume advice simplified:
🎯 Include results with numbers. It’s not enough to have a laundry list of your responsibilities. Employers want to see your impact - what’s better because of YOU.

🎯 Bottom line- recruiters aren’t spending excessive time figuring out if you are a good fit. Your resume needs to make sense to the reader. Avoid jargon and terms that are irrelevant to the job. This is especially important for hashtag#transitioningteachers and hashtag#careerpivots.

🎯Write a strong summary, not an objective. Think of it as your marketing pitch for why you are awesome for the position.

🎯Keep the formatting simple. No photos, emojis, graphs, charts, or references.

🎯 Most people (and 98% of my clients) have 2 page resumes. Include 10-15 years of experience.

🎯 And it should go without saying, your resume should be neat, well formatted, with proper spacing, consistency with fonts, bullet point, alignment, and no spelling mistakes.

hashtag#resumes hashtag#resumewriter hashtag#resumewriting

post_html:
🕒 How I Review 100 Resumes in Under an Hour

Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? It’s easy to get overwhelmed, but there’s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Here’s how I break it down:

1️⃣ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.

2️⃣ Scan for relevant projects: Look for real-world examples where candidates contributed to projects similar to what you need.

3️⃣ Check for career progression: Promotions, increased responsibility, and diverse roles show growth and initiative.

4️⃣ Use keyword searches: Boolean search is your friend! Combine terms like “DevOps AND CI/CD” to narrow the pool.

5️⃣ Pre-set scorecards: Create a scoring system to stay objective. Rate candidates based on skills, experience, and key achievements. No more gut-feeling decisions!

⚡ Pro Tip: Batch your review time—30 focused minutes beats hours of multitasking any day.

Need a breakdown of any of these steps? Let me know!👇

hashtag#RecruitmentTips hashtag#ResumeReview hashtag#HiringSmart hashtag#TechRecruitment hashtag#ScalingTeams hashtag#StartupSuccess hashtag#ProductivityTips

“Why is there a gap in your resume?”


This is the most common interview question that you will encounter if you have a career gap.

But wait- don’t worry.

Here’s how you can answer this question 👇

(This is the exact template)

“I took some time off to [reason for gap, e.g., care for a family member, pursue further education, etc.]. During this period, I [mention any productive activities, e.g., took online courses, volunteered, worked on personal projects] which helped me develop [specific skills relevant to the job]. Now, I’m excited and fully committed to bringing my enhanced skills and experiences to this role.”

That’s all.

post_html:
Reassessing Resume Gaps: A Shift in Perspective

To Employers:
When evaluating candidates, it's crucial to look beyond resume gaps and recognize the inherent value they may bring. Inspired by HBR, consider these tips for assessing career breaks:
- Inquire about the story behind the gap to uncover valuable skills, resilience, or renewed direction.
- Emphasize growth over gaps, acknowledging how candidates use this time to upskill, volunteer, or reflect on their career trajectory.
- Acknowledge the evolving norm of career breaks post-pandemic, understanding its impact on workers' priorities.
- Value authenticity in candidates who address gaps with honesty and confidence, traits they may bring to your team.

Remember, a resume gap signifies more than a pause—it often symbolizes a period of growth, learning, or life management. Keeping an open mind could lead you to your next exceptional hire.

To Job Seekers:
- Address resume gaps directly, focusing on the positive aspects and how they enriched your life or skills.
- Highlight personal growth during the gap, showcasing volunteer work, new skills acquired, or realigned goals.
- Tailor your explanation to the role, emphasizing how your experiences strengthen your candidacy.
- Confidently own your unique career journey, understanding that a gap doesn't define you; it's how you navigate and learn from it that matters.

Have you considered the untapped potential of resume gaps? Individuals with extended breaks have secured remarkable roles by leveraging their distinctive strengths and experiences. Share your insights on uncovering the value within these gaps below!

hashtag#hiring hashtag#jobs hashtag#career

post_html:
12 ways to email like a boss (even if you aren’t one)

Being too nice in emails weakens your message.
It makes people brush off your requests.

----

Here’s a tool to create a professional resume that stands out and passes ATS filters*:
👉🏻 https://lnkd.in/gz4AKJ33

----

Here are 12 email responses to sound more confident:

Addressing a Delay
❌ "Sorry for the delay."
✅ "Thank you for your patience."

Acknowledging a Mistake
❌ "Sorry I missed that."
✅ "Thank you for bringing this to my attention."

Responding to Appreciation
❌ "No worries."
✅ "I’m always happy to assist."

Following Up on Progress
❌ "Just checking in."
✅ "When can I expect an update?"


Ensuring Clarity
❌ "Hopefully that makes sense?"
✅ "Please let me know if you have any questions."

Considering New Ideas
❌ "Maybe we can consider..."
✅ "Let's explore additional options."

Requesting Feedback
❌ "Let me know what you think."
✅ "I’d appreciate your feedback."

Asking for a Review
❌ "If it’s not too much trouble..."
✅ "Could you please take a look and advise?"


Setting Expectations
❌ "I’ll try to get it done by Friday."
✅ "I will have it done by Friday."

Clarifying a Point
❌ "I’m not sure, but..."
✅ "Based on my understanding..."

Addressing a Concern
❌ "I’m a little worried about that."
✅ "There are some concerns we should address."

Proposing a Meeting
❌ "Let me know when you’re free."
✅ "Would you be available to discuss this?"

The right words can change how others respond to you.
Choose them wisely and see better results.

What else would you add?
Let me know in the comments.


♻️ Repost and follow for more expert communication tips

Credit: Lauren Murrell, for the inspiration.

Resume making tips for an impressive and impactful resume.

Tips for Writing an ATS-Friendly Resume:

Use Standard Headings: Stick to common headings like "Work Experience," "Education," and "Skills."

Keep Formatting Simple: Avoid complex layouts, tables, and graphics that might confuse ATS.

Incorporate Keywords: Use job-specific keywords from the job description to ensure your resume matches the job requirements.

Use a Professional Font: Stick to fonts like Arial, Times New Roman, or Calibri to ensure readability.

Your resume is drowning on the INTERNET in the sea full of other resumes!!!!!!

YOU NEED TO STAND OUT!

Here are a couple of extra tips:

#1.) Re-Vamp your resume showcasing impact from you past or current Job. (Growth, % to plan)

2.) Add a small heashot of yourself on your resume.

3.) Reach out to recruiters via LinkedIn
-Introduce yourself(Name, City, position)
-List your years of sales experience
-7 bullet points on your skills and attributes
-Ask if you can email the recruiter your resume
Keep it short (think Twitter/X not Facebook)

✨ Looking for a new job? Avoid these 5 common job search mistakes!
We’ve all been there—endless applications, no responses, and frustration.

Here’s how to improve your chances:
💼 Mistake: Using the same resume for every job
🎯 Fix: Customize your resume with keywords from the job description
💼 Mistake: Ignoring your LinkedIn profile
🎯 Fix: Update your profile with a professional photo, skills, and experiences
💼 Mistake: Relying only on job portals
🎯 Fix: Network and engage with industry professionals
💼 Mistake: Not preparing for interviews
🎯 Fix: Research the company and practice common questions
💼 Mistake: Saying "yes" to the first offer
🎯 Fix: Evaluate offers carefully and negotiate when needed
🔹 Job searching is a process, not a race. Stay patient and keep improving!
What’s your biggest job search lesson? Let’s learn from each other! 💬

hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#Networking hashtag#InterviewTips hashtag#ResumeAdvice

post_html:
A resume is a document that summarizes your skills, experience, and education. It is typically used to apply for jobs.
Here are some tips on how to write a resume:
 * Choose a format.
-‐----------------‐-‐-------------
 There are three main resume formats: chronological, functional, and combination. A chronological resume lists your work experience in reverse chronological order. A functional resume focuses on your skills and abilities. A combination resume combines elements of both chronological and functional resumes.

 * Start with your contact information.
---------------------------------------------------------------
 This includes your name, address, phone number, and email address.
 * Write a resume objective or summary. A resume objective is a statement of your career goals. A resume summary is a brief overview of your skills and experience.

 * List your work experience.
----------------‐-------------------------------
For each job, include the company name, job title, dates of employment, and a brief description of your responsibilities.

 * List your education.
-------------------------------------
 Include the name of the school, degree earned, and graduation date.

 * List your skills.
------------------------------
This can include both hard skills (such as computer skills) and soft skills (such as communication skills).

 * Proofread your resume carefully.
----------------‐-----------------------------------------
Make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.

 * Tailor your resume to the specific job you are applying for.
------------------‐-----------------------------------------------------
Highlight the skills and experience that are most relevant to the job.
Here are some additional tips:
 * Use action verbs to describe your accomplishments.
 * Quantify your accomplishments whenever possible.
 * Keep your resume concise and easy to read.
 * Use a professional font and layout.
-----------------------------------‐----------------------------------

𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐦 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐦𝐞

Making your resume stand out starts with eliminating the clutter. Here’s what you should take off:

1. ❌ Objective Statement – Replace it with a tailored summary or career profile.

2. ❌ Unnecessary Personal Information – Skip details like marital status, full address, or age.

3. ❌ Outdated Work Experience – Remove roles older than 10-15 years unless highly relevant.

4. ❌ Irrelevant Skills – Keep your skill section focused on what’s needed for your target roles.

5. ❌ "References Available Upon Request" – Employers assume you have them.

6. ❌ Short-Term Jobs or Gaps with No Explanation – Make your work history concise and strategic.

7. ❌ Forgetting a professional file name for your resume.

hashtag#jobs hashtag#fresher hashtag#ats hashtag#resumetips

Use These copy-and-paste AI Prompts to Craft a Standout Cover Letter 👇

Make a lasting impression. Get more interviews. Land your dream role!

Try these 7 prompts to supercharge your cover letter:

✉️ Prompt 1: Personalized Opening Creator
Draft an engaging introduction tailored to [Company Name]. Highlight recent initiatives, values, or achievements. Create three variations: one focused on cultural alignment, one on innovation, and one on solving key challenges. Include "connection strength" and "engagement rating" for each. Limit to 75 words. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].

✉️ Prompt 2: Qualification Alignment Mapper
Analyze [Job Title] requirements and match them to my qualifications in a table format with columns for 'Requirement', 'My Experience', and 'Proof of Success'. Add match strength percentages and key talking points. Identify three standout factors that differentiate me. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

✉️ Prompt 3: Success Story Crafter
Generate three impactful success stories tailored to [Target Role] using the Challenge-Action-Result framework. Focus on measurable outcomes and business impact. Rate each story's strength and memorability. Keep each story concise (50 words max). My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

✉️ Prompt 4: Experience-Needs Connector
Create a table linking [Job Title] priorities with my skills and accomplishments. Use columns for 'Company Need', 'My Contribution', and 'Supporting Evidence'. Assign relevance and impact scores for each entry. Limit entries to 15 words each. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

✉️ Prompt 5: Culture Fit Demonstrator
Identify core values and cultural traits from [Company Name]. Write evidence-based statements showing alignment with their mission and ethos. Present in a table with 'Company Value', 'My Experience', and 'Specific Example'. Include authenticity ratings for each match. Company insights: [Paste Research]. My resume: [Paste Resume].

✉️ Prompt 6: Distinct Value Communicator
Write a compelling second paragraph showcasing my unique strengths for [Role]. Develop three versions emphasizing problem-solving, innovation, or team-building skills. Include measurable results and forward-looking statements. Rate differentiation level for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Job description: [Paste Job Description].

✉️ Prompt 7: Passion Statement Builder
Craft an enthusiastic third paragraph expressing excitement about the opportunity at [Company Name]. Incorporate industry knowledge and company-specific insights. Create tailored versions for startups, corporate environments, or growth-stage businesses. Evaluate sincerity signals for each version. My resume: [Paste Resume]. Company insights: [Paste Research].

👉 Follow me for more AI-powered career tips!

🔄 Share this post to help others elevate their job applications!

Harsh truth: resumes auto-generated by job boards? Many hiring managers won’t even consider them. In a sea of applications, a forgettable resume gets lost fast.

🔥 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐬 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐨𝐮𝐭:

🌟 Boost Your Job Search with the Power of High-Quality Recommendations 🌟

In a competitive job market, one of the most effective ways to get your resume noticed is through your network and their recommendations. A well-timed and thoughtful recommendation can make all the difference.

Here’s how you can leverage this to your advantage:

1. Give Your Connections a Heads-Up – If you're planning to mention someone in an interview, let them know in advance. This allows them to be prepared to offer a strong, up-to-date recommendation that highlights your strengths. No one likes to be caught off guard, and you'll get a much stronger, tailored recommendation in return.

post_html:
🚀 Resume Tips to Stand Out!
Your resume isn’t just a document—it’s your personal brand. Make it impactful with these key tips:
1️⃣ Show, Don’t Tell – Instead of claiming you're skilled, prove it through concrete achievements and real-world results.
2️⃣ Skip Overused Buzzwords – Hardworking and team player are filler words. Let your accomplishments speak for themselves.
3️⃣ Showcase Your Career Growth – Highlight promotions to demonstrate your progress and recognition in previous roles.
4️⃣ Put Your Best Work First – Arrange your resume so that your strongest projects and achievements are at the top.
5️⃣ Use Bold Text – Highlight the technologies you used and the impact of your work to make key details stand out.
6️⃣ Keep It Concise – Remove redundancy and keep your resume clear, structured, and to the point.
7️⃣ Maintain a Clean, Professional Look – Skip the photo and fancy designs. A simple black-and-white layout ensures readability and professionalism.
8️⃣ Be Specific, Not Generic – Phrases like "developed multiple APIs" or "fixed several bugs" lack impact. Instead, use measurable details: "Developed RESTful APIs that were responsible to..., improving system performance by 30%."

Your resume should tell a compelling story of your career. hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerGrowth

post_html:
It seems like the purpose of a resume has shifted over the years. What used to be a representation of what I have done has now turned into a mirror of what a job posting says. Why is that?

Resumes are supposed to tell the story of my career — the skills I’ve developed, the challenges I’ve overcome, the value I bring to the table. Yet now, it feels like they are being molded to fit specific keywords and criteria, which often doesn't even capture the full picture of my expertise.

As someone who's looking to transition into a new career field, I’m also facing the challenge of how to reframe my experience. How do I showcase my marketable skills and transferable expertise, especially when my background doesn’t perfectly align with the job titles listed in the postings?

Shouldn’t our resumes reflect our unique capabilities and experiences, not just echo job descriptions? How do we balance staying true to our professional journeys while also satisfying algorithm-driven filters?

What do you think, hashtag#recruiters and hashtag#headhunter community? How do we reclaim the authenticity of our resumes while also ensuring they are seen — especially when making a career transition?

hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerTransition hashtag#JobSeekers hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#ResumeRevolution hashtag#JobPosting hashtag#Hiring hashtag#HR hashtag#TalentAcquisition hashtag#MarketableSkills

6 resume tips for school leavers

Are you about to craft your very first resume as a school leaver? This is a crucial step in starting off your career journey right, and we are right here to help you with it:

1. Highlight your education
Since you likely have less work experience, you need to make your education the focus of your hashtag#resume.

2. Highlight relevant skills
You will develop many job-related skills and transferable skills in your college years. Incorporate them into your hashtag#resume.

3. Talk about extracurricular activities
You can bring out important skills like teamwork, organization, and leadership on your hashtag#resume through extracurricular activities.

4. Write a good summary
The summary statement is an important element of your hashtag#resume. Don’t skip writing it.

5. Create a clean format
Don’t overcrowd your resume with design elements. Keep your hashtag#resume format clean and easy to read.

6. Proofread the document
You can’t afford to make mistakes on your hashtag#resume. Proofread the document before you send it out to employers.

⚠️ Resume Advice Overload? Let’s Talk Truth ⚠️

There are a lot of "gurus" on social media telling you exactly how your resume should look. I'll admit, I’ve shared my fair share of resume tips too.

But here’s the truth: I don’t care what your resume looks like as long as it clearly communicates your skills, experience, and value to the employer.
A particular design won’t get you the job. A resume packed with the right information more than likely will.
✔️ Make it simple.
✔️ Make it clear.
✔️ Make it relevant.

At the end of the day, the goal is to land interviews and get hired.

post_html:
The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:

Including a measurable result

... that you literally can't measure.

ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:

"What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"

But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.

"Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"

Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?

...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?

Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE

You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?"

post_html:
Jeff Nevez, here with APC! I've seen countless resumes pass my desk. Unfortunately, some don’t make it to the next step for common, avoidable reasons. Here's what might be holding yours back:

🔑 Lack of Relevant Experience
 If your experience doesn't align with the job, recruiters may move on. Tailor your resume to highlight the most relevant skills and achievements.

📝 Poor Resume Formatting
 A cluttered or difficult-to-read resume can be a dealbreaker. Stick to a clean format with clear headings and bullet points.

📚 Missing Keywords
 Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) scan for specific keywords. If they’re missing, your resume may be filtered out before anyone sees it.

⏳ Employment Gaps Without Explanation
 Gaps happen, and that’s okay—but explain them. Highlight growth during these periods, whether through learning, caregiving, or volunteering.

🎯 Generic Objective Statements
 Outdated or vague objectives don’t help. Use a strong professional summary to show your value upfront.

🔍 Typos and Grammar Errors
 Mistakes show a lack of attention to detail. Double-check or ask someone to review it for you.

⚠️ Inconsistent or Inaccurate Information
 Inconsistent job titles or inflated claims raise red flags. Honesty is key.

📊 Lack of Measurable Achievements
 Just listing job duties isn’t enough. Show your impact using numbers, percentages, and results.

💡 By addressing these points, you’ll significantly increase your chances of getting noticed. Want more resume tips or career advice? Let’s connect!

What’s your biggest challenge when it comes to resumes? Drop your thoughts below or shoot me a message!

How to write a RESUME so no one can COMPETE

(If you have no idea what to write, open this)

Your resume isn’t being read… it’s being scanned.

For the first 5 seconds, that’s all recruiters do:
Scan ➤ Assess ➤ Move on

If your resume is hard to navigate, guess what happens?
Swipe ➤ Next ➤ Goodbye

It’s harsh, but it’s real. And here’s where it gets even more brutal:

Recruiters are only looking at 6 things.
➊ Contact Info
➋ Location
➌ Summary
➍ Experience/Projects
➎ Education/Courses
➏ Skills

Miss the mark on ANY of these?
You’re risking rejection…
... before your story even gets a chance to be told.

But the solution is simple:
KEEP IT CLEAN. KEEP IT CLEAR. KEEP IT SCAN-FRIENDLY.

Your resume doesn’t have to be perfect.
It just needs to be readable.

Let’s fix this together!

post_html:
💡 Tips for Crafting a Winning Resume! 🚀

Your resume is your personal marketing tool. It needs to capture attention and showcase your skills and experience in the best light possible. Here are some essential tips to make your resume stand out:

1. Clear Contact Information
Make sure your name, phone number, email address, and LinkedIn profile are easy to find. If you have a personal website or portfolio, include that too!

2. Compelling Professional Summary
Kick things off with a brief but powerful summary of your experience, strengths, and career goals. This sets the tone for the rest of your resume.

3. Tailored Skills Section
List relevant skills for the job you're applying for. Focus on a balance of both hard and soft skills that match the role.

4. Achievements Over Responsibilities
Instead of just listing job duties, highlight your key achievements. Quantify your successes with numbers (e.g., increased sales by 30%, led a team of 5).

5. Experience That Shows Impact
Describe your roles using action verbs and focus on the impact you made. This will demonstrate your contribution and value to potential employers.

6. Keep It Concise
A resume should be no longer than 1-2 pages. Be concise and cut out unnecessary information. Employers often skim resumes, so make it easy for them to spot key details.

7. Education & Certifications
List your degrees, certifications, and any additional training relevant to the job. Be sure to include dates and institutions.

8. Use Keywords
Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Include keywords from the job description to ensure your resume gets noticed.

9. Formatting Is Key
Keep your resume clean, professional, and easy to read. Use bullet points, bold for headings, and leave enough white space to make it visually appealing.

10. Proofread, Proofread, Proofread!
Typos can make a bad impression! Always proofread your resume (or ask a friend) to catch any errors.

Remember, your resume is often the first impression a recruiter or hiring manager gets of you, make it count! 🌟

hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#ProfessionalDevelopment hashtag#LinkedInTips hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#CareerAdvice

Here are some quick tips to make your resume shine:

1️⃣ Showcase Projects: Highlight 2-3 key projects, focusing on impact. Use metrics like “Improved system performance by 30%” or “Reduced API response time by 50ms.”

2️⃣ Tailor It: Customize your resume for each role. Match keywords from the job description to your skills and experience.

3️⃣ Keep It Clean: Stick to a clean, professional format. Recruiters spend only 6-8 seconds on a first glance so make it count.

4️⃣ Focus on Skills: List programming languages, tools, and frameworks you're proficient in. Organize them under relevant categories (e.g., Frontend, Backend, Cloud).

5️⃣ Continuous Learning: Highlight certifications, courses, or personal development that show your commitment to growth.

💡 Pro Tip: Your GitHub, portfolio, or LinkedIn profile can seal the deal, make sure they also align with your resume!!

hashtag#SoftwareEngineering hashtag#CareerTips hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#TechCareers hashtag#JobSearch

🚨 The 2 Biggest Resume Mistakes (and How to Fix Them!)🚨

I've reviewed thousands of resumes from students and early-career professionals—and these two mistakes come up all the time.

 1️⃣ Making it too long – Recruiters skim resumes in seconds, so keep it clear and concise. Stick to one page unless you have years of experience!
2️⃣ Poor file naming – A resume titled “Resume_Final(1).pdf” won’t stand out. Use “Name_Role Title.pdf”

Drop your best tips in the comments!
hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#EarlyCareer hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#HomeFromCollege

🔥 5 Resume Tips to Boost Your Job Search in 2025 🔥
1️⃣ Tailor Your Resume – Customize it for each job by using keywords from the job description. ATS-friendly resumes get noticed!
2️⃣ Highlight Achievements, Not Just Duties – Instead of “Managed a team,” say “Led a team of 10, increasing productivity by 30%.” Numbers make an impact!
3️⃣ Keep It Concise – Recruiters spend an average of 6 seconds scanning resumes. Keep it clear, concise, and avoid unnecessary fluff.
4️⃣ Professional Formatting Matters – Use a clean, modern design with consistent fonts and bullet points. Messy layouts can get you rejected instantly.
5️⃣ Include a Strong Summary – A compelling 2-3 sentence professional summary at the top can immediately grab attention. Make it count!

post_html:
Your resume gets 6 seconds.

SIX SECONDS. That’s all recruiters need...

To decide if your CV lands
in the “no thanks” pile.

If your resume is sending the wrong signals,
it’s game over—before you’ve even started.

Here’s how to fix it fast:

1. "I Didn’t Read the Job Posting."
🔴 Red Flag: Clichés like “detail-oriented” or “team player.”
🟢 Fix It: Mirror the job description. Use keywords and highlight specific achievements.

2. "I’m Living in the Past."
🔴 Red Flag: Listing ancient or irrelevant experience.
🟢 Fix It: Focus on the last 10 years. Keep it lean & relevant.

3. "I’m Afraid of Technology."
🔴 Red Flag: No mention of tools or platforms.
🟢 Fix It: Add your tech stack—Excel, Salesforce, or certifications. Digital fluency is mandatory.

4. "I’m Hiding Something."
🔴 Red Flag: Unexplained employment gaps.
🟢 Fix It: Fill the gaps—showcase freelancing, volunteering, or upskilling. Control the narrative.

5. "I Don’t Sweat the Details."
🔴 Red Flag: Typos, inconsistent formatting, outdated info.
🟢 Fix It: Use Grammarly. Polished resumes show you care.

6. "I Have No Results to Show."
🔴 Red Flag: Vague phrases like “managed a team” or “responsible for projects.”
🟢 Fix It: Quantify everything:
“Boosted sales by 25%” > “Managed a team.”

7. "I’m Just Sending This Everywhere."
🔴 Red Flag: Generic resumes sent to every job.
🟢 Fix It: Highlight wins that match the job description.

8. "I’m Desperate."
🔴 Red Flag: Applying for every job under the sun.
🟢 Fix It: Stay focused. Align your resume to roles that tell one clear story.

🔥 Your Resume = Your Pitch.

If it’s not selling your story,
it’s time for a rewrite.

What is your resume really saying about you?

♻️ Share this to help someone today!
🔔 And follow Aslant Legal for more.

post_html:
Insomnia is a pain in the ass. I can’t sleep.

So here are 3 resume tips for breaking into US companies.

1️⃣. Place the country your job is based next to
Company name. It shows you have already
 Worked in a US/EU startup.

2️⃣. Eliminate your picture from the resume. It
Might be custom where you are but it isn’t
For US companies and can take page space.

3️⃣. Don’t make your font too small. If you struggle
 To read your resume, so will the recruiter.


Hope these quick tips help💪.

hashtag#recruiting hashtag#hiring hashtag#startups hashtag#latam

post_html:
Most people don’t know how to use ChatGPT for job search.

But it doesn't have to be that way.

Here are 10 ChatGPT resume prompts to land your dream job:

Role-specific Resumes:

"You are Resume GPT, an expert in crafting industry-specific resumes. Using the input {job_title} and {skills}, create a resume tailored for this role. Ensure it aligns with {industry_standards}, emphasizing {achievements} and {keywords}."

Resume Revamp:

"Take this resume: {resume_content} and improve it for {job_title}. Focus on clarity, strong action verbs, quantifiable achievements, and ATS optimization. Highlight transferable skills if applicable."

Resume from Scratch:

"Generate a professional resume for {job_title} based on the following: {experience}, {education}, {skills}, and {certifications}. Ensure it includes a strong summary and action-driven bullet points."

Highlight Achievements:

"Using {job_title} and {achievements}, craft three strong bullet points showcasing impactful results. Use metrics and action verbs, ensuring relevance to {industry}."

Career Switch Focus:

"Help rewrite a resume for a career switcher moving from {current_role} to {desired_role}. Emphasize transferable skills, achievements, and soft skills relevant to the new role."

Formatting Optimization:

"Review this resume content: {resume_content} and reformat it for clarity and professionalism. Ensure optimal use of {layout_style} and proper alignment with {ATS} standards."

Objective Statement Writing:

"Write a compelling resume objective for someone seeking a {job_title} role. The focus is on {goals}, {skills}, and {industry expertise} to grab recruiters' attention."

Entry-level Resumes:

"Create a resume for an entry-level candidate with the following: {education}, {internships}, {skills}, and {projects}. Highlight achievements in coursework or extracurriculars."

Executive Resume:

"Develop an executive-level resume for {job_title} with an emphasis on {leadership}, {strategic impact}, and {revenue growth}. Use concise language and quantified accomplishments."

Cover Letter Pairing:

"Pair this resume {resume_content} with a tailored cover letter for {job_title}. Highlight {key_achievements}, why {company_name} is appealing, and how the candidate's skills meet {job_requirements}."

Thanks for checking...

Interested in learning more about how to use ChatGPT?

post_html:
Most résumés are boring and forgettable.

Here’s how to make yours stand out.

Most people treat their résumé like a history book, listing every job they’ve had and every task they’ve done.

But hiring managers don’t need a timeline, they need a reason to say YES.

Here’s how to make your résumé stand out in a way most people overlook:

🔹 Write for the Future, Not the Past
 Your résumé should position you for the job you WANT, not just reflect what you’ve done. Tailor your skills and accomplishments to align with the next step in your career.

🔹 Your Job Title Isn’t Enough, Show the Impact
 Instead of “Managed training programs,” say “Designed and implemented training programs that increased employee productivity by 30%.” Numbers tell a story.

🔹 Your Summary Shouldn’t Be Boring
 Avoid clichés like “hardworking professional seeking opportunities.” Instead, answer: What makes you different? Why should they hire YOU?

🔹 Remove Fluff That Wastes Space
 Phrases like “responsible for” or “assisted with” weaken your impact. Get straight to the result. What did you do? What happened because of it?

🔹 Make It Easy to Skim
 Hiring managers scan résumés in seconds. Use bold headings, bullet points, and clear formatting so they can see your value fast.

Your résumé isn’t just a document, it’s your first impression.

Make them want to know more.

Does your résumé sell your value or just list your past?

hashtag#ResumeTips

What’s One Resume Tip That Made a Huge Difference for You?

A resume isn’t just a document—it’s your professional story. One tip that transformed how I approach resumes is focusing on achievements instead of job duties. Hiring managers want to see impact, not just responsibilities!

Here are some simple yet powerful resume tips:
✅ Use action verbs – Words like "led," "optimized," and "implemented" add strength.
✅ Quantify your results – Numbers make your accomplishments more compelling.
✅ Keep it concise – Recruiters spend seconds scanning resumes, so clarity matters.
✅ Tailor for each job – One-size-fits-all resumes don’t work in a competitive job market.

What’s one resume tip that helped you stand out? Let’s share and learn from each other!

post_html:
Wrote a client's resume today. 📝

Most people overthink this step, but after writing thousands of resumes, I’ve learned a few counterintuitive truths.

Here are 3 quick contrarian resume writing tips:

1️⃣ Write less, not more. Hiring managers skim. The more you write, the less they retain.
2️⃣ You are less important than the company’s needs. Your resume isn’t about you—it’s about how you solve their problems.
3️⃣ Stop trying to make it look pretty. Fancy designs don’t get jobs. Clear, scannable formatting does.

Hope that’s helpful.

Most people overthink this step, but after writing thousands of resumes, I’ve learned a few counterintuitive truths.

Here are 3 quick contrarian resume writing tips:

1️⃣ Write less, not more. Hiring managers skim. The more you write, the less they retain.
2️⃣ You are less important than the company’s needs. Your resume isn’t about you—it’s about how you solve their problems.
3️⃣ Stop trying to make it look pretty. Fancy designs don’t get jobs. Clear, scannable formatting does.

Hope that’s helpful.

post_html:
👀 Is Your Resume Easy to Read?

After you’ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if it’s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Here’s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out:
🔍 Top-to-Bottom Flow
Does your resume naturally guide the reader’s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? That’s the most critical part—if it’s hard to find, you’re doing yourself a disservice.

📂 Key Details at a Glance
Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.

🎯 Communicating Accomplishments
Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments you’d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.

💡 Pro Tip
If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. It's one of the most common questions hiring managers have when reviewing a resume. "What's that company do?"

hashtag#resumetips hashtag#recruiterthoughts hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#resume2025

post_html:
Recently, I reviewed a resume so GOOD, it made me pause in the middle of my lunch & call the candidate to schedule an interview.

It wasn't just the layout or the fancy font that caught my eye; it was the clear, concise way the candidate's achievements and experiences were presented.

It was evident they had done their homework, tailoring their resume specifically for the role, making it impossible to ignore.

So, what's the recipe for a standout resume? 📄✨

1. 𝐂𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐦𝐢𝐳𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐊𝐞𝐲: Don't send out a one-size-fits-all resume. Tailor it to the job you're applying for, highlighting the experience and skills that align with the job description.


2. 𝐂𝐥𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬: Keep it clear and to the point. Use bullet points to break down your achievements and make them easy to read.


3. 𝐍𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐒𝐩𝐞𝐚𝐤 𝐋𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫: Quantify your achievements. Increased sales by 20%? Reduced project delivery times by 30%? These figures grab attention.


4. 𝐀𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐌𝐚𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐬: Choose a clean, professional template that makes your resume easy on the eyes. But remember, simplicity doesn't mean boring.


5. 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝, 𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐟𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐀𝐠𝐚𝐢𝐧: Typos and grammatical errors can be the kiss of death for your application. Double-check, then have someone else check too.

𝐀𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮'𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐭, 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐜 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.

✅ Its simple math, you need the job >> you got to demonstrate why you're the perfect fit for the role.

So, take that extra time to craft a resume that reflects the best version of you. It might just be the reason you land your dream job. 💼🌈

Follow Priya Vajpeyi For More!
hashtag#JobHunt hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#CareerGrowth hashtag#MakeAnImpact

Say Goodbye to countless job Interviews.
ChatGPT is a powerful tool that can enhance your job applications 😎 💻
Don't forget to share this post with your friends ♻️
Here are 10 prompts that will help you land your dream job👇🏽:

✅ Resume Updates ~
1. [Prompt]: "Provide tips and best practices for optimizing a resume to ensure it is compatible with Applicant Tracking Systems."
2. [Prompt]: "Provide recommendations to improve the formatting and layout of the following resume section."

✅ LinkedIn Summary ~
3. [Prompt]: "Craft a concise and compelling summary for my LinkedIn profile that highlights my professional journey, key skills, and what makes me unique. Keep the tone conversational and ensure the length does not exceed 150 words. Please find the attached resume for reference."
My Resume: [Paste Your Resume]
4. [Prompt]: "Please help me create a LinkedIn headline that effectively communicates my experience, qualifications, and unique value. Consider incorporating keywords relevant to my industry as mentioned in the resume below and showcasing my passion or mission. My headline should be a snapshot that captures attention and encourages visitors to explore my profile further."
My Resume: [Paste Your Resume]

✅ Tailoring Your Cover Letter ~
5. [Prompt]: "Given below is the job description for [Job Title] at [Company], generate key points and skills that should be highlighted in the cover letter."
6. [Prompt]: "Based on the identified key points, craft a compelling introduction paragraph for a cover letter addressing the job [Job Title] at [Company]."

✅ Mock Interview Help ~
7. [Prompt]: "I’m interviewing for [job title] at [Company]. Generate a set of common interview questions tailored to it"
8. [Prompt]: "Image yourself as the interviewer and conduct a mock interview for the [Job Title] position, ask me a series of questions, and provide feedback on all of my responses."
9. [Prompt]: What are some common interview questions a hiring manager could ask at a company that [explain what the company is/does]?
10. [Prompt]: How do I best answer [common interview question] if I’m interviewing for a role as [job title] at [company/type of company]?

Use our Job assistant platform to get your dream job today 🚀
⚡️ Careerflow.ai: https://lnkd.in/drNZrQkX

🚀 Stay Ready, So You Don’t Have to Get Ready!

Your résumé isn’t just for job hunting—it’s your career highlight reel.

✨ Opportunities or Layoffs can come when you least expect them and having an updated résumé means you’re always prepared to say YES to new beginnings!

🔹 Career growth? Update it.
🔹 New skills or certifications? Add them.
🔹 Big wins at work? Showcase them.

An up-to-date résumé keeps you confident, prepared, and in control of your career journey. Don’t wait until you need it—keep it ready!

When was the last time you updated yours? Drop a ✅ in the comments if you’re committed to keeping it fresh!

post_html:
💥 Day 96 of hashtag#100ResumeTips: Share value fast!

Imagine for a moment that you need assistance with a pain point. Let's say your requirement is a plumbing issue in your home. You go to the bookstore seeking a book on basic plumbing. When you arrive at the bookstore, hundreds of books are in the plumbing section.

You start picking books off the shelf and giving them a quick scan.

During the scan, if a book doesn't immediately catch your eye and address your needs - the chances are high that you will move on to the next one.

Your resume is no different. It may only get a quick scan. If it does not immediately address the reader's needs and provide value fast - it may get passed over.

post_html:
Top 5 resume tips that get you interviews:

1. Lead with the section of your resume with the most value.

Example: if you don't have any experience but have a Masters in Business Analytics, start your resume with your education section.

2. Show specific, numeric impact.

Example: Increased gross revenue by 3% as measure by...

❌ don't use generic or fake percentages like 20% or 50%. If you cant measure impact, don't use a percentage.

3. Only include skills that you can validate.

Example: If you include Machine Learning in your skills section, you better have some machine learning project or experience in your resume.

4. Add the title you want to be on your resume.

Example: if you have done data analytics at a previous job, but you worked in operations, ask your previous manager if you can change the job title to data analyst on your linkedin and resume.

5. Use 𝗯𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 strategically.

❌ don't bold skills
✅ bold your impact or outcome of a project

what important resume tips am I missing?

hashtag#dataanalytics hashtag#resume hashtag#tips

post_html:
I don't understand why people don't use ChatGPT for job searches.

ChatGPT can 10X your interview chances.

Copy and paste these ChatGPT prompts to land your dream job in 2024:

1. Company Research

"I have an interview with [company] for the position of [job position]. Please summarize the company's mission, core products or services, and recent news or achievements by analyzing their website [website link] and any recent press releases."

2. Resume Optimization

"Review my current resume attached and suggest improvements tailored for applying to a [job position] at [company]. Highlight any gaps in my experience and recommend ways to address these through online courses or projects."

3. Cover Letter Writing

"Based on the job description for [job position] at [company], generate a cover letter that highlights my relevant experience, skills, and why I am passionate about working for [company]."

4. Interview Preparation

"For the position of [job position] at [company], what are some industry-specific challenges or trends I should be aware of? How can I demonstrate my understanding or propose potential solutions during the interview?"

5. Common Interview Questions

"Generate a list of common interview questions for a [job position] role within the [industry] industry."
